newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: SCHIPHOL-NOISE COMPLIANCE HARDER AFTER COURT ORDER.
newsitem.headline: SCHIPHOL-NOISE COMPLIANCE HARDER AFTER COURT ORDER.

text.p: Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport said on Friday an interim court ruling suspending its imposition of a ban on night flights by wide-body aircraft would further hamper the airport's efforts to stay within legal noise limits.
"Schiphol stands by its view that each of its proposed restrictions is necessary in order to avoid exceeding the noise limit," airport spokeswoman Ingrid Bouw said.

The Haarlem district court ruled earlier that restrictions on night-time take-offs of noiser wide-body aircraft should be suspended until it gives a verdict next Friday in a case brought by airport users.

"Every delay does make it harder for us to meet the noise criteria," Bouw said. "But until the court's final verdict next Friday we cannot impose the ban on wide-body night flights between 11 pm and six am (2100-0400 GMT)."

Dutch charter airline Martinair, air cargo association ATAN, freight handler Aero Ground Services and Israeli airline El Al joined forces to seek a court injunction preventing Schiphol from imposing the ban.
Martinair argues that its Boeing 747-200 flights should not be prevented from taking off as the aircraft qualifies as a so-called low-noise Chapter Three aircraft.
The ban formally took effect on August 5, but airlines had been given a period of grace until Monday, Bouw said.

"Up until now we have been working with a system of 'yellow cards', warning airlines who chose to ignore the take-off ban," she said. "From Monday we would have forcibly stopped aircraft from taking off."
However, such measures had now been rendered impossible by the court order, she said.
